title: "How can meditation on food and pleasure lead to spiritual experiences as mentioned in Tantric scriptures?"
first_phrase: In the final 200 tokens of this text, the focus is on a meditation exercise that rewires our thoughts and associations with food. By shifting our attention towards the sensation of hunger as energy rather than on a specific food craving, we can experience a deep meditative state. This is consistent with the teachings of Swami Muktananda to meditate on oneself. The author recommends focusing on the delightful sensations of food and sexuality as energy, rather than the object of that pleasure in order to exeperience a deeper connection with ourselves.
content: If you want to lose weight, you can use this meditation when you're hungry, i.e., focus your attention on hunger as energy rather than on a food fantasy and notice what happens. That's a whole meditation but you can't do it if you're not hungry. ________________ Chapter VIII You can use the sensations and joy of a chocolate chip cookie or an ice-cream soda or whatever. Take your awareness away from it and meditate on the sensations. To paraphrase the Vijnana Bhairava, Focus your attention on the delight (as energy) rather than on the object of delight (chocolate, etc.). If it's sexuality, meditate on the delight, rather than on the object. If you're having sex with somebody, you're more than likely focusing on the person. Turn your attention away from the person toward the delight itself and see what the experience is. With foodoit's the same. There's really only one teaching that Swami Muktananada ever had and that was to meditate on yourself. This can be seen at the biological dimension as meditating on the delight as energy rather than on the object of delight as food (or a sexual object).
last_phrase: In conclusion, focusing on the sensations of delight and joy instead of the object of our desires can be a powerful tool in meditation. Whether it's food or sex, the ability to turn our attention inward and become aware of our reactions can help us become more mindful and in control of our impulses. So next time you're feeling hungry, try meditating on the energy of hunger rather than on a specific food and see what happens.
